metadata.description: This dataset contains the monthly evaporation rate and volumes for 7242 reservoirs from March 1984 to December 2016 across the world. The evaporation rate was calculated using the three datasets viz. (1) TerraClimate; (2) ERA5; (3) Princeton Global Forcings. The surface area of these reservoirs is obtained from the Global reservoir surface area dataset (GRSAD). The detailed descriptions for this dataset are presented in Tian et al (2021,2022). The basic information of the global reservoirs was provided by  the Global Reservoir and Dam Database (GRanD).
metadata.instructions:
File name: the reservoir evaporation data is stored in text format, and the file name is "sta.txt", where sta is the reservoir site number, and the number source is the information in GRanD  v1.3.
Data reading method: all ASCII files in the data set can be directly opened with text programs (such as Notepad). Except for the header file, the main content is numerical representation of the evaporation rate and evaporation volume of the corresponding reservoir under the three meteorological forcing.

background: Reservoirs play a key role in water resources management, including water supply, hydropower generation, and flood control. About 16.7 million reservoirs with a surface area larger than 100 m² have been built worldwide. With the increase in the number of reservoirs, total water surface area of global reservoirs increased from 4.11 × 10⁵ km² in 1984 to 4.48 × 10⁵ km² in 2015, leading to increased reservoir evaporation losses. From a global perspective, Shiklomanov (1999) estimated that global reservoir evaporation volume is about 188 km³ in 1995, which is larger than global domestic and industrial water consumption of the year (~132 km³). From a regional perspective, Zhao and Gao (2019) showed that annual total reservoir evaporation from large reservoirs (storage capacity greater than 0.1 km³) in the United States is equivalent to 93% of annual public water supply of the country in 2010. Reservoir evaporation volume is calculated by multiplying reservoir surface area and evaporation rate. Reservoir surface area can be estimated from field measurement and remote sensing images. Compared with the field measurement, the method using remote sensing images has advantages of low cost, global coverage, and easy access. The Penman equation and its variants can calculate the effect of heat storage of large reservoir on evaporation. The effect can be calculated using the equilibrium temperature, which is the water temperature without heat exchange between air and water under constant forcing.
research objective: As the world's largest developing country, China has built about 98,822 reservoirs by 2018. These reservoirs bring a lot of evaporation losses; thus, it is necessary to accurately estimate reservoir evaporation losses in China. In this study, we estimated monthly reservoir evaporation for large reservoirs of China from 1985 to 2018 using the GRSAD and the Penman equation incorporated with the heat storage.
methods: Monthly surface areas of the 916 reservoirs were obtained from the GRSAD. Monthly meteorological variables for evaporation calculation include air temperature (Tₐ), vapor pressure deficit (VPD), surface shortwave radiation (SSR), and wind speed (u). The Penman equation was used to calculate reservoir evaporation rate, and it has been widely validated in the estimation of open water evaporation. For each reservoir, monthly reservoir evaporation volume was calculated by multiplying monthly reservoir surface area and monthly evaporation rate.
dataset: The Global Reservoir and Dam Database (GRanD) collects basic information of 916 large reservoirs in China, such as location, depth, and storage capacity. Monthly surface areas of the 916 reservoirs were obtained from the GRSAD. Monthly meteorological variables for evaporation calculation include air temperature (Tₐ), vapor pressure deficit (VPD), surface shortwave radiation (SSR), and wind speed (u). These data were obtained from TerraClimate dataset with a spatial resolution of 1/24°.
findings: Total evaporation losses significantly increased (p < 0.05) because of significant increases in evaporation rate (p < 0.05) and reservoir surface area (p < 0.05) from 1985 to 2018. In 2018, total reservoir evaporation losses were 140.2 × 10⁸ m³, which is about 1.1 times the amount of water transferred in the Middle Route of the South-to-North Water Transfer Project in China. Total evaporation losses of large reservoirs in China are significantly smaller than that in the United States, although total storage capacities of large reservoirs in the two countries are similar. This is mainly due to the larger average depth and smaller area of China's large reservoirs.
